Hydro Pump is better into Wide Guard users such as Zamazenta-C and Lunala, while Origin Pulse is a spread move. Thunder allows Kyogre to threaten the Water-type Pokemon that resist its Water-type attacks such as Kyogre and Urshifu-R, while Ice Beam lets Kyogre threaten the Dragon- and Grass-type Pokemon that do the same such as Miraidon and Rillaboom.
  • Mystic Water boosts Kyogre's Water-type attacks even further, letting it OHKO most Calyrex-S sets.
  • The Speed investment allows Kyogre to outspeed base 135 Speed Pokemon after an Icy Wind. The HP investment allows Kyogre to live a Thunderbolt from bulky Magnet Raging Bolt, and the rest of the EVs are dumped into Special Attack.
  • Tera Grass is used to give Kyogre a resistance to the Grass- and Electric-type attacks that threaten it. This is especially helpful to prevent priority attacks such as Rillaboom's Grassy Glide and Raging Bolt's Thunderclap from weakening Kyogre's Water Spout too much. Tera Grass also lets Kyogre ignore Rage Powder and Spore from Amoonguss, letting it potentially get an attack off into Amoonguss's partner.

Teambuilding

  • Because Kyogre runs at least two Water-type moves, it often has to choose which Pokemon it will be checked by. Rillaboom and Raging Bolt are problems if Kyogre runs Thunder, opposing Kyogre can be an issue if it runs Ice Beam, and all three are problematic if it runs Origin Pulse. Koraidon and Miraidon are also problematic, as they resist Kyogre's Water-type attacks; Koraidon also changes the weather, weaking Kyogre's attacks.
  • Calyrex-I pairs well with Kyogre, as it threatens Rillaboom, Raging Bolt, Koraidon, and Miraidon for super effective damage. It can also set Trick Room against faster teams, letting Kyogre use Water Spout without having to worry about taking damage. Zacian-C and Zamazenta-C are both good partners as well because of their good damage output, letting Kyogre clean up weakened foes or letting them clean up after Kyogre has weakened them with Water Spout. Zacian-C is especially good into Miraidon and Raging Bolt, while Zamazenta-C is better at spreading damage.
  • Amoonguss can heal Kyogre with Pollen Puff, letting it spam Water Spout against slower foes. It can also redirect attacks away from Kyogre, keeping it safe and letting it use Water Spout without worrying about faster foes. Tailwind setters like Roaring Moon, Tornadus, and Iron Jugulis help Kyogre against faster foes if they do not also have a Tailwind setter. Tornadus and Iron Jugulis can also threaten Grass-type Pokemon and Koraidon, while Roaring Moon can use Knock Off to remove Assault Vest from Iron Hands and Rillaboom.

Bulky Attacker.description:
Set Details

  • Groudon uses its good physical bulk and strong attacks to spread damage throughout a game while being difficult to remove. Groudon matches up especially well into Miraidon and Raging Bolt because of its immunity to their Electric-type attacks and ability to threaten them with Ground-type attacks.
  • High Horsepower is used as a stronger single-target alternative to Precipice Blades, allowing Groudon to get around Wide Guard from Pokemon like Lunala. Crunch is used on Assault Vest sets to threaten Calyrex-S and Lunala for super effective damage.
  • Clear Amulet blocks Intimidate from Incineroar, letting Groudon fire off attacks without having to worry about its damage being reduced. Assault Vest boosts Groudon's Special Defense, allowing it to survive Draco Meteor from Choice Specs Miraidon.
  • The HP and Special Defense investment allow Groudon to survive Draco Meteor from Choice Specs Miraidon outside of Electric Terrain if it isn't running an Assault Vest or, if it is running an Assault Vest, survive Draco Meteor if Electric Terrain is active. The Speed investment lets Groudon outspeed Choice Scarf Urshifu if Tailwind is active. The Attack investment ensures that Groudon will OHKO bulkless Miraidon with Precipice Blades almost all of the time.
  • Tera Fire lets Groudon resist the Ice- and Grass-type attacks that threaten it before it Terastallizes such as Glacial Lance from Calyrex-I and Wood Hammer from Rillaboom. Tera Fire also boosts Heat Crash's damage, letting Groudon OHKO Calyrex-S with it.

Teambuilding

  • Groudon struggles into Kyogre because it can override Groudon's sun and threaten to OHKO it with Water Spout and Hydro Pump or deal a large amount of damage with Origin Pulse. Groudon also struggles into physically defensive foes that it cannot hit for super effective damage, such as Terastallized Calyrex-I and Lunala, as Groudon cannot do enough damage to them before being KOed.
  • Groudon pairs well with Pokemon with Protosynthesis like Raging Bolt and Flutter Mane, as it allows them to run items other than Booster Energy. Raging Bolt threatens Kyogre, while Groudon threatens the Steel-, Poison-, and Fire-types that resist Flutter Mane's Fairy-type attacks.
  • Grimmsnarl's dual screens boost Groudon's bulk even further. Incineroar and Volcarona both benefit from Groudon's sun boosting their Fire-type attacks and weakening Water-type attacks from Urshifu-R. They also threaten Calyrex-I, helping Groudon break through it.
  • Restricted Pokemon that can threaten large amounts of damage, such as Miraidon and Calyrex-I, are good partners for Groudon, as their additional damage helps into bulkier foes. Miraidon also threatens to OHKO Kyogre and can do good damage to Lunala and Calyrex-I.

Garchomp.comments:
Teambuilding

  • Garchomp fits well onto a variety of teams. It isn't capable of surviving multiple strong attacks, so it relies on partners that allow it to attack without receiving a lot of damage in return. Priority Tailwind setters like Talonflame and Whimsicott are great partners, and they both provide additional Taunt support to disrupt Trick Room setters like Porygon2. Fake Out users like Incineroar disrupt foes for Garchomp. Incineroar additionally provides damage reduction via Intimidate and Parting Shot. Garchomp also works well on balance teams featuring Porygon2, as Garchomp threatens Gholdengo and Incineroar, both of which Porygon2 and its common partners struggle to damage. Garchomp additionally performs well on beatdown teams featuring Dragonite, as Garchomp can freely attack with Earthquake without damaging it.
  • Amoonguss and Vivillon provide redirection and sleep support; Amoonguss is bulkier and has a more consistent way of putting foes to sleep, while Vivillon is faster and is immune to Garchomp's Earthquake. Garchomp pairs well with Porygon2; Porygon2 setting Trick Room can allow Garchomp to attack before threats like Dragapult. Porygon2 additionally deals significant damage to Grass- and Flying-types with Ice Beam and can comfortably survive Earthquake while regaining the lost HP with Recover. Dragonite also synergizes well with Garchomp. Dragonite can deal strong damage with Extreme Speed, allowing Garchomp to secure KOs with Earthquake and removes Grass-types like Rillaboom, which Garchomp struggles to KO, with Tera Blast Flying.
  • Garchomp is threatened by Dragon-, Fairy-, and Ice-type attacks like Dragon Darts and Outrage from Dragapult, Moonblast from Clefable, and Blizzard from Alolan Ninetales. All of these attacks can be switched into by Steel-type partners such as Gholdengo and Kingambit. Garchomp also struggles to damage Flying-types like Pelipper, especially when it isn't using Rock Slide, so a partner like Alolan Ninetales easily threatens Flying-types with Blizzard and Freeze-Dry.

Strategy Comments

  • As a glass cannon, Garchomp's task is to deal as much damage as possible uninterrupted. Garchomp performs best when it outspeeds its foes and when it is supported by redirection, allowing Garchomp to attack freely.
  • Garchomp excels at being an early-game sweeper as well as a late-game cleaner. Garchomp primarily attacks using Earthquake to damage both foes. It uses Stomping Tantrum when Garchomp's partner is vulnerable to the damage from Earthquake or when Grassy Terrain is active. Dragon Claw and Rock Slide are used to damage foes that resist Earthquake and Stomping Tantrum.
  • Dragapult outspeeds and threatens Garchomp. To beat Dragapult, Garchomp needs Tailwind or Trick Room support, allowing it to threaten Dragapult with Dragon Claw before it attacks. A partner Kingambit can also survive an attack from Dragapult and threaten it in return with Kowtow Cleave or before Dragapult attacks with Sucker Punch. Rillaboom is also troublesome for Garchomp, as Grassy Terrain weakens the damage of Earthquake. Garchomp is very reliant on partners like Talonflame and Dragonite to remove Rillaboom, as it struggles to deal threatening spread damage when Grassy Terrain is active.

Glass Cannon.description:
• Garchomp utilizes its high Attack and good Speed to outspeed and greatly weaken foes with powerful spread damage.
  • Using both Stomping Tantrum and Earthquake allows Garchomp to switch between dealing single-target and spread damage. Earthquake, however, is used most effectively when Garchomp's partner is able to use Protect or is immune to Ground-type attacks. Rock Slide is most commonly used by Choice Band Garchomp to threaten Flying-types like Talonflame and Pelipper. It is used as an alternative spread damage attack that doesn't affect Garchomp's partner and is unhindered by Grassy Terrain set by a partner Rillaboom.
  • Life Orb boosts Garchomp's damage, allowing it to threaten an OHKO onto +1 Defense Sneasler with Stomping Tantrum or Earthquake and Dragonite with Dragon Claw. Clear Amulet is used to block Intimidate and Parting Shot from Incineroar. Choice Band provides a greater damage increase than Life Orb, allowing it to threaten an OHKO onto Gholdengo with Stomping Tantrum or Earthquake at the cost of being unable to switch between attacks. The item choice greatly affects Garchomp. Life Orb and Choice Band sets are subject to having its Attack dropped by Incineroar cycling Intimidate and Parting Shot, while the damage from Clear Amulet sets is less.
  • Tera Steel inverts Garchomp's weaknesses to Fairy-, Dragon-, and Ice-type attacks such as Moonblast from Clefable, Outrage from Dragonite, and Blizzard from Alolan Ninetales; additionally, it allows Garchomp to resist Choice Specs-boosted Tera Steel Make It Rain from Gholdengo. Tera Ground increases the damage of Stomping Tantrum and Earthquake, allowing Garchomp to OHKO Gholdengo. Tera Fire provides similar resistances as Tera Steel while not granting a weakness to Fighting-type attacks, and it provides an immunity to burn.

Gallade.comments:
Teambuilding

  • Gallade isn't a particularly bulky Pokemon, so it is often paired with partners more capable of setting up Trick Room while Gallade threatens foes that threaten its partners. Gallade also can be paired with redirection that allows it to set up Trick Room.
  • Hatterene pairs well with Gallade, as it is more capable of setting Trick Room up thanks to its bulk, while Gallade threatens foes such as Incineroar and Kingambit that Hatterene struggles to damage in return. Hatterene additionally threatens physically defensive foes that Gallade struggles to OHKO such as Amoonguss and provides powerful spread damage with Dazzling Gleam, which complements Gallade when it fails to achieve an OHKO. Indeedee-F provides redirection, allowing Gallade to safely set up Trick Room. It is additionally capable of setting up Trick Room itself while Gallade provides Wide Guard support. Indeedee-F setting up Psychic Terrain further supports Gallade by preventing Fake Out disruption and increasing the damage of Psycho Cut.
  • Amoonguss threatens to put Gallade to sleep with Spore, often forcing it to Terastallize into a Grass-type. A partner Torkoal threatens Amoonguss with Eruption and Weather Ball and outspeeds it while Trick Room is active. Gholdengo is difficult for Gallade to remove and threatens to deal significant damage with its STAB attacks. Torkoal and Ursaluna can survive Gholdengo's attacks and threaten it in return with Eruption and Headlong Rush. Basculegion-M threatens Gallade with its STAB attacks, so a partner Kingambit is capable of surviving these attacks and threatening it with Sucker Punch and Kowtow Cleave.

Strategy Comments

  • Gallade is a sweeper and a support Pokemon for Trick Room teams. It performs best early-game by removing threats preventing Trick Room from being set up or setting up Trick Room itself.
  • Gallade should always be led with a partner capable of setting Trick Room such as Hatterene or Indeedee-F. If paired with Hatterene, Gallade can be used to remove threats such as Kingambit and Incineroar. When facing Gholdengo, it can use Wide Guard to protect Hatterene from Make It Rain. If Gallade is paired with Indeedee-F, it can set Trick Room as Indeedee-F redirects attacks with Follow Me. However, there may be situations where Indeedee-F can be used to set up Trick Room itself while Gallade removes an opposing threat like Kingambit. Gallade can also use Wide Guard while Indeedee-F sets up Trick Room, protecting both Pokemon from attacks like Eruption from Hisuian Typhlosion.
  • Gallade is checked by Ghost-types and threatened by their attacks like Shadow Ball and Last Respects. As a result, Gallade is very reliant on redirection from Indeedee-F or switching to it if Indeedee-F is not lead. Gallade also relies on Kingambit to threaten them.
  • Foes with Imprison like Indeedee-M disrupt Trick Room teams and are often difficult for Gallade to remove, so it relies on partners like Ursaluna and Kingambit for this. If the opponent pivots around to stall out Trick Room turns, getting KOs while Trick Room is active becomes difficult for Gallade and its partners. To mitigate this, overwhelming the foes with powerful attacks from teammates like Ursaluna helps to reduce the effectiveness of the switches.

Offensive Trick Room Sweeper.description:
• Gallade is an offensive threat thanks to Sharpness and its ability to set Trick Room up for itself and its partners.
  • Sacred Sword ignores the Defense boosts of foes like Archaludon and Dondozo. Psycho Cut is used as a consistent Psychic-type STAB move that is also boosted by Sharpness. Its damage can be boosted further by a partner's Psychic Terrain. Wide Guard protects Gallade and its partner from spread attacks such as Make It Rain and Eruption.
  • Clear Amulet prevents Gallade's Attack from being hindered by Intimidate and Parting Shot, allowing it to always deal threatening damage to metagame staples such as Incineroar.
  • Tera Grass provides Gallade with an immunity to Spore, Sleep Powder, and Rage Powder while allowing it to resist Electro Shot from Archaludon. Tera Fire, unlike Tera Grass, removes Gallade's weakness to Flying-type attacks such as Hurricane from Pelipper without gaining a weakness to Poison-type attacks such as Dire Claw from Sneasler, and it also allows Gallade to resist Make It Rain from Gholdengo. Tera Fire additionally provides an immunity to burn.

Whimsicott.comments:
Teambuilding

  • Whimsicott generally works well on hyper offensive teams that appreciate its ability to provide speed control and shut down opposing setup threats with Encore. Pokemon that have middling or high Speed tiers and strong offenses pair especially well with Whimsicott. Whimsicott can also work well on sun-centric teams, utilizing its ability to overwrite Pelipper's Drizzle with Sunny Day to maintain speed and weather control.

  • Whimsicott pairs especially well with strong special attackers, namely Hisuian Typhlosion, Glimmora, Power Herb Archaludon, Gholdengo, and Garchomp. Their middling Speed tiers benefit greatly from Tailwind, and Hisuian Typhlosion in particular also appreciates Whimsicott's ability to set sun, boosting its Eruption further while mitigating its Water weakness. Annihilape can be used on some teams that want to employ Beat Up strategies, which can also be effective.

  • Whimsicott can struggle into teams that can handle its partner's offensive onslaught or mitigate Whimsicott's Tailwind Speed advantage. However, by changing up Whimsicott's partner, it can break through some defensive cores that may stop one pairing but not the other. For example, while Incineroar may be able to beat Whimsicott and Hisuian Typhlosion, it loses to Meteor Beam Glimmora. Since Whimsicott generally pairs with strong, fast offensive threats, its playstyle is very vunerable to Trick Room, especially teams that have Psychic Terrain, which blocks Whimsicott's Prankster Encore. Due to this, Whimsicott generally likes to pair with Incineroar to shut down Trick Room teams while also allowing Whimsicott's frailer partners to pivot in safely.

Strategy Comments

  • Whimsicott exists as a support Pokemon, providing speed control through Prankster Tailwind and amplifying its partner's damage output through Helping Hand or Sunny Day.
  • Whimsicott is almost always a lead Pokemon, with a hard-hitting partner that takes advantage of its Tailwind support. It almost always wants to be clicking Tailwind to gain the Speed advantage immediately, unless it is facing a Trick Room team that can turn that advantage on its head. Against bulkier cores that may not have speed control or care about moving first, Whimsicott may choose to use Helping Hand or Sunny Day to try to break through those cores with its partner's sheer power.
  • Whimsicott is mainly weak to strong priority that can take it out before it can set Tailwind, mainly Tera Normal Extreme Speed from Dragonite and Brave Bird from Talonflame. Pokemon that can stomach many hits and slow down the level of offense coming from Whimsicott's side can also be a problem, since Whimsicott is so frail that it can usually only afford to set Tailwind or Sunny Day once. By choosing certain partners for Whimsicott, this matchup problem can be turned on its head. Pokemon such as Glimmora can beat common counters to Whimsicott, including Talonflame, Dragonite, and Incineroar. Pokemon that block priority moves can also support Whimsicott, such as Indeedee with Psychic Terrain and Farigiraf with Armor Tail.

Tailwind Support.description:
• Whimsicott is a staple on hyper offense teams due to its ability to set Tailwind with its Prankster ability. Whimsicott also provides valuable support to its team through the use of Encore to disrupt opposing strategies or Helping Hand and Sunny Day to boost its partner's damage output.
  • Encore is generally preferred to be able to pin opposing Pokemon into positions where they cannot use Protect, dissuade setup, and lock opposing Pokemon into moves such as Fake Out or Tailwind. Helping Hand is the preferred last move on Whimsicott for most teams because it provides a damage boost to any of Whimsicott's partners. Sunny Day is used on certain hyper offense teams to boost Hisuian Typhlosion's Eruption and provide weather control against Pelipper. Protect is almost always used on Focus Sash sets to block Fake Out without the need to Terastallize into a Ghost-type. Beat Up is specifically used with Annihilape to boost its Rage Fist; this, in conjunction with Tailwind, makes it into a threat as quickly as possible.
  • Covert Cloak is generally preferred on Whimsicott to block the effects of Fake Out, allowing Whimsicott to get Tailwind off without having to run Protect. However, Focus Sash is sometimes used on teams that want Whimsicott's support on the field for longer. Focus Sash also allows Whimsicott to set Tailwind in front of Talonflame, which would otherwise KO Whimsicott before it can set Tailwind with Brave Bird in conjunction with Gale Wings.
  • Tera Water can be used to give Covert Cloak Whimsicott an extra turn on the field against common Pokemon such as Incineroar, Hisuian Typhlosion, and Gholdengo, though it must watch out for Rillaboom's now supereffective priority Grassy Glide. Tera Ghost gives Whimsicott an immunity to common priority moves, namely Fake Out and Extreme Speed and is usually seen on Focus Sash sets, as they are susceptible to Fake Out. Tera Fire offers similar defensive benefits to Tera Water while still resisting Rillaboom's Grassy Glide after Terastallization. However, Tera Fire makes Whimsicott weak to common moves such a as Primarina's Liquid Voice Hyper Voice and Pelipper's Weather Ball under rain. Tera Dark is a niche option on Focus Sash sets that gives Whimsicott an immunity to opposing Prankster moves from the likes of Murkrow and opposing Whimsicott.
  • The first spread for Covert Cloak Whimsicott maximizes HP investment over damage output to live attacks that would otherwise prevent it from setting Tailwind. Focus Sash sets, on the other hand, invest more into Special Attack.

Amoonguss.comments:
Teambuilding

  • Amoonguss generally likes bulkier partners that can play long games with lots of switching because of its ability to find a time to sleep an important part of the opposing team in order to allow a partner like Gholdengo or Kingambit to set up and sweep.
  • Incineroar is a great partner for Amoonguss, as it switches into the Fire- and Ice-type attacks that threaten Amoonguss, lowers opposing Pokemon's Attack with Intimidate, which makes Amoonguss even harder to KO, and can help Amoonguss find times to switch out in order to get healing from Regenerator with Fake Out and Parting Shot. Porygon2 is another strong partner, setting Trick Room for Amoonguss while benefiting from Amoonguss redirecting Fighting-type attacks that threaten it and Taunt, which could prevent Porygon2 from setting Trick Room or healing with Recover.
  • Amoonguss is very weak into Pokemon that it cannot put to sleep like Gholdengo, Safety Goggles Incineroar, and Rillaboom, as its attacks will not be doing very much damage while its foes can freely set up or attack into its teammates. Incineroar can help with this, since it can threaten Gholdengo and Rillaboom with Flare Blitz and remove opposing Safety Goggles with Knock Off.

Strategy Comments

  • Amoonguss mainly works as a bulky support Pokemon. Ideally, it can find value at any point in the game, as healing from Sitrus Berry and Regenerator let it stay healthy.
  • Amoonguss's presence on a team works to force the opponent to bring Pokemon that cannot be put to sleep. This can be taken advantage of by not bringing Amoonguss game one of a set but bringing it game two where the opponent could respect it less.
  • Amoonguss's biggest checks are Pokemon that it cannot put to sleep with Spore, whether it's Gholdengo, Grass-types like Rillaboom and opposing Amoonguss, or Safety Goggles Pokemon like Incineroar and Kingambit. This can be played around by pivoting around Spore immunities with Amoonguss to try and find a time to put an important Pokemon to sleep.

Bulky Support.description:
• Amoonguss's main purpose is to disrupt the opposing team with Spore while protecting teammates with Rage Powder and healing them through Pollen Puff.
  • Protect is the best fourth move most of the time because it means that the opponent can not freely double target Amoonguss. Clear Smog can be used as an answer to Dondozo teams, but it is not required to beat Dondozo as Amoonguss's best friend Incineroar can cycle Intimidate and Parting Shot to weaken Dondozo while Amoonguss uses Spore to put it to sleep.
  • Sitrus Berry lets Amoonguss avoid being KOed by a double up or being KOed by three hits of Dragon Darts from Dragapult. Rocky Helmet lets Amoonguss punish physical attackers like Basculegion-M, Annihilape, and Maushold that want to use contact moves like Wave Crash, Rage Fist, and Population Bomb into Amoonguss's partners with Rage Powder.
  • Tera Water lets Amoonguss resist attacks like Make It Rain from Gholdengo, Blizzard from Alolan Ninetales, and Flare Blitz from Incineroar at the cost of becoming weak to Wood Hammer from Rillaboom. Tera Fairy is used on teams that have a rough Kingambit matchup, letting Amoonguss easily redirect its attacks and put it to sleep with Spore while being a typing not weak to most of the metagame's attacks; however, it means that Amoonguss can't resist Make It Rain from Gholdengo, a Pokemon that it struggles with already.
  • The defensive investment lets Amoonguss survive Hurricane from Pelipper, 150-Base Power Last Respects from Basculegion-M, Blood Moon from Life Orb Ursaluna-B, Guts-boosted Facade from Ursaluna, and Flare Blitz from Incineroar. 27 Speed IVs let it underspeed the Ursaluna formes in Trick Room.

Hydreigon.comments:
Teambuilding

  • Hydreigon is fast and offensive, so it works best on offensive teams. It appreciates having physical attackers next to it that can break down the special walls that Hydreigon struggles to break through, like Tyranitar and Sylveon. Hydreigon also enjoys having Tailwind and redirection support; Tailwind lets Hydreigon outspeed key threats like Dragapult, and redirection moves keep away threats like a Moonblast from Primarina. Choice Specs sets work even better with hyper-offensive playstyles due to the immense damage it can output.

  • Hydreigon appreciates Clefable, as it can support Hydreigon with Follow Me, absorbing dangerous Fairy-, Fighting-, and Dragon-type attacks like Moonblast, Outrage, and Close Combat. Hydreigon works well with powerful Ground-type attackers such as Garchomp and Ursaluna that can hit the Pokemon that Hydreigon cannot such as Archaludon with Earthquake, which Hydreigon is unaffected by. It also enjoys the presence of Gholdengo, which can switch in against status moves or Fake Out and threaten Fairy-types. Tailwind support from Talonflame or Whimsicott is also favored by Hydreigon for boosting Speed.

  • Hydreigon's main weakness is its inability to outspeed faster Dragon-types without Tailwind and its dangerous 4x weakness to Fairy. It also has a hard time hitting special walls like Tyranitar and Primarina. To mitigate this, it's important to have strong physical attackers on the team like Garchomp and Annihilape that can quickly empty the opposing team of special walls; to deal with faster Dragon-types, a Tailwind setter like Murkrow is necessary, and a Steel-type like Gholdengo will quickly rid the opposing team of Fairy-types.

Strategy Comments

  • Hydreigon fulfills its main role on teams as a damage dealer through its great stats and typing. It absolutely shines the most during the early-game, when it can spread heavy damage, then switch out and clean up other pieces late-game.

  • Hydreigon is best used when the opposing team no longer has any healthy special walls so that it can use its respectable Special Attack to pick off everything else.

  • Hydreigon has its biggest problems against Pokémon that hard check and threaten it, such as Primarina and Archaludon. It's best to position your team to where these walls are either gone or heavily damaged before sending Hydreigon out to deal with them. Redirection from Clefable is also very appreciated to allow Hydreigon to spread damage uncontested.

Glass Cannon.description:
• Hydreigon uses its high Special Attack stat and good Speed stat to make it one of the faster and stronger threats in the current metagame. With its good offensive typing, Hydreigon ends up being a large threat to much of the metagame, such as Gholdengo and Garchomp.

  • Heat Wave provides Hydreigon with coverage against Kingambit, Rillaboom, and Tera Steel Gholdengo. Snarl gives Hydreigon a STAB option that lowers damage from foes like Archaludon.

  • Life Orb allows Hydreigon to use Protect and switch moves, whereas Choice Specs makes way for more damage but is less flexible. For instance, Choice Specs guarantees an OHKO on Ursaluna-B with a Draco Meteor, but Life Orb only guarantees a 2HKO.

  • Tera Poison and Tera Fire pair extremely well with Hydreigon due to both of them flipping some of Hydreigon's weaknesses into resistances. Tera Fire synergizes well with Heat Wave, providing a damage boost and letting Hydreigon resist Make It Rain's from Gholdengo; meanwhile, Tera Poison completely walls out Sneasler. Both options benefit from Levitate, negating the Ground weakness and making the Ursaluna formes and Garchomp less threatening.

Volcarona.comments:
Teambuilding

  • Setup Volcarona fits well on balance teams, as it requires utility and defensive support to enable it to sweep.
  • Rillaboom is an excellent teammate, as it uses Fake Out to give Volcarona room to set up and sets up Grassy Terrain that augments Volcarona's passive recovery and powers up Giga Drain. Redirectors like Clefable draw attacks away from Volcarona, letting it set up more easily. Intimidate users like Incineroar supplement Volcarona's ability to enhance its special bulk by reducing the damage of physical attackers.
  • Kingambit is a common teammate on the balance teams that Volcarona fits on. Assault Vest variants threaten foes like Incineroar, Tyranitar, and Dragapult that Volcarona struggles against. Another common choice on balance teams is Sneasler, which can threaten Rock-types and Incineroar that stuff Volcarona, and it can use Fake Out to give Volcarona room to set up or Coaching to bolster Volcarona's physical bulk.
  • If Volcarona has not Terastallized into a Fairy-type, it struggles with Dragon-types like Dragonite, so Fairy- and Dragon-types like Clefable and Dragapult can help it with that. Volcarona, before Terastallizing into a Grass- or Dragon-type, hates Water- and Rock-types like Basculegion-M and Tyranitar, so Grass-types like Rillaboom give it leeway against them. Additionally, Volcarona's coverage does not extend to Fire-types like Incineroar; Water-types like Primarina threaten them. Primarina also checks Dragon-types, making it a uniquely good teammate.

Strategy Comments

  • As a setup sweeper, Volcarona wants Fake Out support and redirection to give it breathing room to set up. The earlier in the game Volcarona can get set up, the more difficult it will be to remove it from the field, as a boosted Volcarona will be able to take multiple special attacks. Intimidate cycling assists in this, as it reinforces Volcarona's physical bulk to complement Quiver Dance, which boosts its special bulk.
  • Volcarona is actually one of the greatest adversaries of rain teams, as with redirection support from Electabuzz and Terastallization, it can boost to a level where it takes the special attacks of the rain attackers with ease. From there, its boosted attacks will rip apart these rain attackers and completely deny them the ability to revenge kill it. In these matchups, it's better to avoid using too many attacks on Archaludon, as its Stamina-boosted Body Press will eventually become too strong for Volcarona to handle. Early in the game, Pelipper threatens Volcarona with both of its STAB moves, so redirection will prevent Volcarona from being KOed by Pelipper before it can get set up. Additionally, Swift Swim Basculegion-M is a threat before Volcarona has set up, easily outspeeding and overwhelming it with rain-boosted Water-type attacks.
  • Volcarona lacks coverage to threaten Dragon-types unless it has Terastallized into a Fairy-type, so the likes of Dragapult and Dragonite can take it on effectively. This extends to Tera Dragon Pokemon like Gholdengo, which gain the ability to resist its Fire-type STAB moves. Fairy- and fast Dragon-types like Clefable and Scale Shot Dragonite threaten these Dragon-types. Similarly, Fire-types like Incineroar and Tera Fire users like Rillaboom can deal with both of its attacks, and they are also immune to burns from Heat Wave and Flame Body; Water-types like Primarina can deal with these Pokemon. If Volcarona is not using Tera Grass Giga Drain, then Water- and Rock-types like Primarina and Garganacl give it issues; Grass-types like Rillaboom can assist Volcarona in this vein. Trick Room teams invalidate Volcarona's Speed boost, though the Special Defense boost enables it to take attacks from the special attackers on these teams. Another useful tactic is to use physical attackers, as it has worse Defense and cannot improve it with Quiver Dance, though Volcarona can mitigate this issue with Intimidate support.

Bulky Setup Sweeper.description:
• Volcarona utilizes the bulk, power, and Speed granted by Quiver Dance; its useful coverage; and Terastallization, which lets it work its way around its checks, to become difficult to take down and take over games as a result.
  • Tera Blast Fairy lets Volcarona defeat Dragon-types that can stand up to Heat Wave; Giga Drain hits Water- and Rock-types while providing additional recovery to let Volcarona stay on the field longer. Tera Blast is used only on Tera Fairy sets, whereas Giga Drain sees play on Tera Grass and Tera Dragon sets.
  • Covert Cloak lets Volcarona ignore Fake Out to set up or throw out its attacks more freely, and it prevents Snarl, Icy Wind, and Dire Claw from impeding its sweep. Leftovers gives Volcarona passive recovery, augmenting the recovery that Giga Drain provides to be at higher HP to survive more attacks.
  • Tera Fairy lets Volcarona bypass Dragon-type attacks like Dragapult's Dragon Darts and Dragonite's Scale Shot and maintain a resistance to Fighting-type attacks like Sneasler's Close Combat. Tera Grass gives Volcarona a resistance to Water- and Electric-type attacks like Basculegion's Wave Crash and Archaludon's Electro Shot, makes it immune to Amoonguss's Spore, and powers up Giga Drain, turning +1 Giga Drain from a 2HKO into an OHKO on Basculegion and doing the same with +2 Giga Drain for Primarina. This additionally lets it restore more HP in the process, making it more likely to sweep games. Tera Dragon gives Volcarona similar defensive benefits and doesn't make it weak to Pelipper's Hurricane, Sneasler's Dire Claw, and Fire-type attacks like Armarouge's Armor Cannon and Incineroar's Flare Blitz, though it becomes weak to Dragon-type attacks like Dragapult's Dragon Darts and Dondozo's Order Up.
  • 180 Speed EVs and a Timid nature ensure that Volcarona will outspeed Annihilape, as well as other mid-speed Pokemon like Gholdengo and Archaludon. With 164 Special Attack EVs, Tera Blast Fairy will OHKO offensive Dragapult, as well as maximum HP Annihilape after a Quiver Dance. The bulk investment ensures that Volcarona survives a Tera Normal Blood Moon from Life Orb Ursaluna-B after a Quiver Dance and, after Terastallizing, two Rock Slides from Tyranitar if Leftovers or Rillaboom's Grassy Terrain are in play to neutralize sandstorm damage.
  • Alternatively, Volcarona can lean into its bulk with maximum HP investment, which can benefit from the recovery offered by Giga Drain. After the aforementioned Speed investment to outspeed Annihilape, the rest of the EVs are put into Defense, letting Volcarona survive physical priority moves like Black Glasses Kingambit's Tera Dark Sucker Punch and Choice Band Dragonite's Tera Normal Extreme Speed. Even with minimal Special Defense investment, Volcarona has enough special bulk to survive Pelipper's Hurricane; after a Quiver Dance, it will take a Blood Moon from Tera Normal Life Orb Ursaluna-B or a Choice Scarf Tera Fire Overheat from Hisuian Typhlosion in sun, assuming it hasn't Terastallized into a Grass-type.

Bulky Redirector.description:
Set Details

  • Volcarona has a solid place in Regulation I due to its ability to function as a support piece for its team, using redirection to protect its teammates and punish physical attackers, most notably Urshifu-R, Zamazenta-C, and Iron Hands, with Rocky Helmet and potential Flame Body burns. It can utilize Struggle Bug and other moves such as Will-O-Wisp to further support its team while outputting strong damage using its Fire-type STAB move.
  • Fiery Dance is the Fire-type STAB option for Volcarona, being able to boost its damage output while dealing sizeable damage, with the damage boost allowing for it to potentially pick up a 2HKO on Calyrex-I and Rillaboom. Will-O-Wisp can be used to neuter physical threats such as Calyrex-I and Zamazenta-C without relying on Flame Body, while Tailwind can allow Volcarona to support its team through speed control. Struggle Bug allows Volcarona to hamper the opponent's special offense while dealing decent damage and breaking Focus Sashes, which is particularly problematic for opposing Calyrex-S; it also can break Lunala's Shadow Shield while crippling its offense.
  • Rocky Helmet in tandem with Flame Body punishes contact moves greatly, especially those that come from Urshifu-R, while Electric Seed can be used on Miraidon teams to further bolster Volcarona's physical bulk and afford it more survivability, most importantly allowing it to live a Life Orb Flare Blitz from Koraidon.
  • The first EV spread allows Volcarona to take a +1 Life Orb Calyrex-S Astral Barrage and a Choice Specs Miraidon Volt Switch the majority of the time, three Glacial Lances from Calyrex-I and a Tera Fire Flame Charge from Life Orb Koraidon while allowing Volcarona to outspeed Adamant Urshifu-R. The second EV spread allows Volcarona to take two Sword of Ruin-boosted Body Presses from Zamazenta-C, two Sucker Punches from Chien-Pao, and a +2 Astral Barrage from Calyrex-S without a boosting item.
  • Tera Dragon allows Volcarona to resist Water-, Fire- and Electric-type attacks from the likes of Urshifu-R, Ogerpon-H, and Miraidon, respectively, allowing Volcarona to maintain a strong defensive presence. Tera Water provides a resistance to the aforementioned Water- and Fire-type attacks while crucially maintaining a resistance to Glacial Lance from Calyrex-I after Terastallizing.

Teambuilding

  • Ogerpon-C is very problematic for Volcarona, as it is able to threaten to OHKO it with Ivy Cudgel, which also avoids Rocky Helmet and Flame Body due to it not making contact, while ignoring Rage Powder due to its Grass typing and still dealing large damage after Volcarona Terastallizes. Similarly, Miraidon can threaten Volcarona with massive damage before and after Terastallization while not being threatened by it in return.
  • Foes that have powerful spread options, namely Calyrex-S and Kyogre, can also be problematic, as they can deal massive damage to Volcarona and its partner while ignoring Volcarona's redirection.
  • Miraidon pairs amazingly with Volcarona, as Volcarona can protect Miraidon from powerful attacks, notably Ice Spinner from Chien-Pao and Play Rough from Zacian-C, while threatening Rillaboom, which can be problematic for Miraidon. In return, Miraidon can hit Water- and Flying-types like Urshifu-R, Kyogre, and Tornadus with massive damage from its Electric-type STAB moves.
  • Calyrex-I also pairs very effectively with Volcarona, with Calyrex-I greatly appreciating redirection to allow it to safely set Trick Room and sweep; it also hits Dragon-types that can threaten Volcarona such as Miraidon and Koraidon with Glacial Lance.
  • Zamazenta-C partners well with Volcarona, with Volcarona's redirection allowing Zamazenta-C to stay safe, notably from Koraidon. Zamazenta-C's Wide Guard alleviates Volcarona's weakness to spread and its Body Press threatens Ogerpon-C.
  • Grimmsnarl can set up dual screens to assist Volcarona in supporting the team, while Volcarona's redirection can assist Grimmsnarl to in safely setting the screens up, and they both form a strong utility core for a team. Iron Hands threatens many common counters to Volcarona, notably Ogerpon-C and Kyogre, while Iron Hands greatly appreciates Volcarona's redirection and ability to threaten Amoonguss and Rillaboom.
  • Rillaboom itself pairs well with Volcarona, with Rillaboom threatening Water-types like Urshifu-R and Kyogre, and Volcarona in return hits Amoonguss and other Grass-types that can wall Rillaboom.

Bulky Tailwind.description:
Set Details

  • Tornadus is one of two viable priority Tailwind setters in the metagame, pairing excellently with Restricted Pokemon like Calyrex-S, Zamazenta-C, and Kyogre that appreciate its combination of weather control, speed control, and Flying-type STAB moves that allow it to threaten Restricted Pokemon like Koraidon as well as non-Restricted Pokemon like Amoonguss, Rillaboom, and the Urshifu formes.
  • Bleakwind Storm is used for strong spread Flying-type STAB damage, while Hurricane is chosen to hit through the Wide Guard used by Zamazenta and Lunala while securing an OHKO on the Urshifu formes. Hurricane is only an option on Kyogre teams due to its inconsistency outside of rain. Rain Dance deactivates Koraidon's Orichalcum Pulse and significantly weakens its Fire-type moves while also setting up the rain for its own Water-type partners like Urshifu-R and Kyogre. Taunt is chosen to prevent status moves like Zamazenta-C's Wide Guard, Amoonguss's Spore, and Calyrex-I or Lunala's Trick Room that would disable or take advantage of Tornadus and its partners, Kyogre and Calyrex-S. Generally, Tornadus runs Protect on non-Covert Cloak sets in order to avoid flinches from Fake Out or on offensive teams that do not need Rain Dance and would prefer the increased staying power generated by Protect.
  • Covert Cloak is chosen to allow Tornadus to set up Tailwind against Fake Out Pokemon like Incineroar and Rillaboom that would otherwise leave it vulnerable to being KOed or pressure it into using Protect . Rocky Helmet is chosen in order to allow Tornadus to punish Urshifu-R and Koraidon, forcing them to take significant recoil.
  • The Speed investment allows Tornadus to outspeed maximum Speed Groudon and Kyogre, while the bulk investment allows Tornadus to survive Tera Water Surging Strikes from Urshifu-R or Thunderclap from Raging Bolt.
  • Tera Dark is chosen to allow Tornadus to block Taunt from opposing Tornadus and Encore from opposing Whimsicott, while also providing it a key resistance to Calyrex-S's STAB moves.

Teambuilding

  • Raging Bolt and Miraidon threaten to OHKO Tornadus with their STAB Electric-type moves, being able to OHKO it with a Special Attack Protosynthesis-boosted Thunderclap, which takes Tornadus out before it can move, or Volt Switch, which creates momentum for the opposing team, respectively. Tornadus also hates Pokemon that are able to set up Trick Room against it while threatening to OHKO it, with Restricted Pokemon like Calyrex-I and Meteor Beam Lunala being able dissuade Tornadus's Taunt with their offensive pressure. Indeedee-F and Farigaraf also present unique challenges to Tornadus, as the two of them are able to set up Trick Room while also blocking Tornadus's Prankster Taunt with their abilities. While Tornadus can OHKO Whimsicott, its Speed combined with Prankster Encore allow it to shut down Tornadus and punish it for using Tailwind or prevent it altogether with Taunt.
  • Urshifu-R is Tornadus's premier partner, being able to take advantage of both the Tailwind and Rain Dance it sets up in order to do massive damage uncontested by Protect. Rillaboom is able to contest Indeedee-F and Miraidon's Terrains, threatening the former and switching in on the latter while also applying Fake Out pressure, allowing Tornadus to more effectively set Tailwind throughout the course of a game. Landorus is notable for its ability to OHKO both Raging Bolt and Miraidon while appreciating Tornadus's Tailwind allowing it to outspeed threats like Calyrex-S, Zamazenta-C, and the aforementioned Miraidon.
  • Kyogre is another of Tornadus's primary partners, with Tornadus being able to hit Grass-types like Rillaboom, Amoonguss, and the Ogerpon formes super effectively with its Flying-type attacks for it while also being able to reset rain into opposing weather control. Tornadus appreciates Kyogre's ability to output immense damage into Trick Room setters like Calyrex-I, Lunala, Farigiraf, and Indeedee-F, allowing it to freely set Tailwind for its partners. Calyrex-S also greatly appreciates Tornadus's Tailwind, which allows it to gain an advantage against opposing Calyrex-S and Koraidon. Tornadus's Taunt support is vital for both Restricted Pokemon, as it is able to prevent Zamazenta-C and Lunala from using Wide Guard. Zacian-C is a also a notable partner because it appreciates Tornadus's ability to set Tailwind against Miraidon and Calyrex-S while taking advantage of its ability to set rain in the face of Koraidon. Zacian-C is also able to handle a lot of Tornadus's checks, since it is able to outspeed and OHKO Raging Bolt, Miraidon, and most Calyrex-I.

Offensive Support.description:
Set Details

  • Sharp Beak Tornadus is a bulky offensive support Pokemon that can output decent damage with Bleakwind Storm. It has positive matchups versus various metagame staples, such as Koraidon, Rillaboom, and Amoonguss, as well as good neutral matchups into much more of the metagame.
  • Taunt provides disruption, denying otherwise crippling plays from opposing supporting moves; it's especially helpful for Trick Room and Wide Guard users, since negating those allow Tailwind and Bleakwind Storm to be effective.
  • Sharp Beak lets Tornadus be more flexible, since it will be able to deal good chip damage even when Taunted; this allows Tornadus to run more bulk. With the Sharp Beak, it has a chance to OHKO Koraidon and 2HKOes Amoonguss and Rillaboom.
  • The Defense and HP investment allows Tornadus to live a Behemoth Blade from +1 Zacian-C and a Surging Strikes from Mystic Water Urshifu-R; the Special Defense investment allows Tornadus to survive an Astral Barrage or a Psychic from a Life Orb Calyrex-S. The Speed investment lets Tornadus outspeed the entire unboosted metagame under Tailwind, as well as letting partner Smeargle outspeed and use Decorate on Tornadus, letting +2 Tornadus 2HKO bulky Pokemon like Zamazenta-C. The remaining EVs are invested into Special Attack.
  • Tera Dragon lets it live a Water Spout in rain from Kyogre, a Flare Blitz from Koraidon in sun, a Meteor Beam from Lunala, or an Overheat from Modest Chi-Yu.

Teambuilding

  • Tornadus dislikes opposing Whimsicott, since a Taunt or Encore will largely limit Tornadus's usefulness. It's also susceptible to Fake Out users like Incineroar and Iron Hands, as it doesn't have Covert Cloak or Tera Ghost.
  • Tornadus is countered by Raging Bolt, Miraidon, and Calyrex-I, all of which threaten OHKOs on Tornadus both before and after Terastallizing and can easily take Bleakwind Storms multiple times.
  • Tornadus appreciates Smeargle, since Smeargle can redirect dangerous Electro Drifts, Thunderclaps, and Thunderbolts from Miraidon and Raging Bolt, respectively, and can block opposing Glacial Lances, Water Spouts, and Origin Pulses from Calyrex-I and Kyogre, respectively, with Wide Guard.
  • Restricted Pokémon like Zamazenta-C, Calyrex-S, and Kyogre appreciate being around Tornadus, since it can let them outspeed everything with Tailwind, excluding Speed Booster Energy Iron Treads and Flutter Mane. Tornadus can also deny opposing Wide Guard with Taunt, letting Calyrex-S and Kyogre freely fire off Astral Barrage and Water Spout, respectively.
  • Rillaboom acts as a check to Raging Bolt and Miraidon, easily tanking Electric-type damage for Tornadus while getting rid of Electric Terrain. It is also important Fake Out support that moves before Incineroar and Iron Hands.
  • Raging Bolt is also a wonderful partner for Tornadus, since they cover each other great defensively and together have nigh-unresisted coverage; additionally, Raging Bolt can revenge kill Miraidon and opposing Raging Bolt after Tailwind has been set up.

Life Orb.description:
Set Details

  • Landorus is a powerful offensive Pokemon able to threaten massive damage to many common metagame fixtures with its Life Orb- and Sheer Force-boosted Earth Power, Sludge Bomb, and Sandsear Storm.
  • Sludge Bomb allows Landorus to threaten super effective damage into Tera Fairy Miraidon, Ogerpon-H, Ogerpon-W, Grimmsnarl, and any other Pokemon that utilize Tera Fairy.
  • Sandsear Storm provides Landorus with powerful, spread Ground-type damage for Miraidon, Zamazenta-C, and Incineroar. Taunt gives Landorus a great option into Pokemon that use dual screens, Wide Guard, or Trick Room, shutting down those options for Pokemon like Grimmsnarl and Lunala.
  • Life Orb and Sheer Force enable Landorus to pick up most of its KOs, most notably OHKOing Miraidon and Incineroar with Earth Power and 2HKOing Rillaboom with Sludge Bomb.
  • The offensive investment allows Landorus to OHKO Urshifu-R with no defensive investment with Earth Power, while Landorus's defensive investment allows it to live a Choice Band Surging Strikes from Urshifu-R when Landorus is Terastallized, as well as living a Choice Specs Miraidon's Draco Meteor when Landorus is behind Light Screen.
  • Tera Poison allows Landorus to remove its weaknesses to Water- and Ice-type attacks like Surging Strikes from Urshifu-R and Ice Spinner from Chien-Pao that typically give it a lot of trouble while increasing the power of Sludge Bomb, which most notably turns Sludge Bomb into an OHKO into Rillaboom following Wood Hammer recoil.

Teambuilding

  • Landorus's typing means that it is threatened by Calyrex-I and Kyogre, which can easily OHKO Landorus. Koraidon can also pose an issue to Landorus, as it can outspeed and OHKO Landorus with Flare Blitz.
  • Chien-Pao is another major threat to Landorus, as it threatens to outspeed and OHKO Landorus with its Ice-type attacks. Amoonguss can also be a difficult foe, as Amoonguss always survives any attack Landorus uses and can use Spore to immobilize it.
  • Grimmsnarl partners well with Landorus, giving it some much needed bulk and support with dual screens while slowing down opposing Pokemon such as Koraidon with Thunder Wave, which can allow Landorus to outspeed them and threaten massive damage. This especially supports matchups into Kyogre and Koraidon, as dual screens prevent OHKOs from Flare Blitz and any of Kyogre's moves after Landorus has Terastallized.
  • Incineroar is also a very good partner, as Intimidate weakens the damage output of Calyrex-I and Koraidon, unless they are holding a Clear Amulet, which can be removed with Knock Off. Will-O-Wisp also cripples Calyrex-I's and Chien-Pao's damage output, regardless of what item Calyrex-I runs.
  • Miraidon pairs naturally with Landorus, as it poses a threat to many of the top dangers to Landorus, such as Kyogre and Koraidon, with powerful Electric-, Fairy-, and Dragon-type attacks, while Landorus deals massive damage to some of Miraidon's biggest counterplay in Zamazenta-C and Rillaboom.
  • Landorus also is a great partner to Calyrex-I, as Landorus is able to threaten the Fire-types that scare Calyrex-I, such as Incineroar and Chi-Yu, while Calyrex-I can use Glacial Lance to deal significant damage to Amoonguss and Koraidon.

Talonflame.comments:
Teambuilding

  • Talonflame is most common as the main supportive option on teams that aim to overwhelm the opponent and win quickly, such as hyper offense, where priority speed control in the form of Tailwind is especially valuable. Its most common partner by far is Choice Specs Gholdengo, which, when paired with Covert Cloak Talonflame, prevents Fake Out and makes it difficult to stop a turn one Tailwind + Tera Steel Make it Rain. This duo is also particularly strong with Dondozo and Commander Tatsugiri, softening up teams for Dondozo to clean up in the endgame.
  • Talonflame doesn't particularly need any partners to function well; it instead serves to complement its teammates.
  • Talonflame's main competition is Whimsicott, which doesn't have to worry about about losing access to priority moves thanks to Prankster, as well as having better enabling tools such as Sunny Day for Hisuian Typhlosion and Delphox and Beat Up for Annihilape. Talonflame has more general utility tools with Will-O-Wisp and non-Prankster Taunt, is faster, and can OHKO it first with priority Brave Bird, but it generally isn't as support-oriented as Whimsicott.

Strategy Comments

  • Talonflame's biggest strength is immediate turn one pressure. Take advantage of that. You generally always want to be leading Talonflame and setting up Tailwind; going for an attack is risky before Tailwind is up, as you lose Gale Wings and a significant chunk of Talonflame's health. Once Tailwind is up, sacrificing it for a free switch is usually the play. If you have the opportunity for a safe switch, however, take it, as Talonflame's coverage and Speed makes it a great late-game cleaner.
  • The only real reason to use Talonflame over Whimsicott is coverage and damage, functioning almost like a glass cannon with access to priority Tailwind. Flying- and Fire-type coverage is excellent into the metagame, and its Speed means it's always a credible threat. Go for damage whenever possible after setting up Tailwind.
  • The best way to handle Talonflame is to nullify either its damage or priority speed control. Pokemon with Intimidate severely hamper Talonflame's offensive pressure, and even Pokemon like Electabuzz and Primarina that can eat one of its attacks and return back for strong damage are difficult matchups. Alternatively, nullifying its priority or Speed advantage also works well. Priority attacks like Fake Out and Extreme Speed break Gale Wings, with the former often completely preventing Tailwind from being set up on non-Covert Cloak sets. Priority blocking abilities like both Indeedee's Psychic Surge are difficult but not common. Incineroar is likely the biggest pain spot for Talonflame teams, as it walls Gholdengo, can break Gale Wings with Fake Out, and has Intimidate to cripple Talonflame offensively. If you're playing Talonflame, you have to be careful when leading it into Incineroar and Sneasler teams, and usually, it's best to completely leave it behind in matchups against balance teams.

Offensive Tailwind Support.description:
• Talonflame takes over for Tornadus as the premier offensive Tailwind support, dealing huge damage with its primary STAB attacks that give it immediate offensive pressure as well as having a host of supportive options with Gale Wings Tailwind.
  • Covert Cloak is the most popular item on Talonflame, preventing opposing Fake Outs from slowing down a offensive lead. Talonflame's high Speed means it's usually not too bothered by Gale Wings breaking. Life Orb and Sharp Beak are two sides of the same coin; they are offensive items to pick up OHKOes on foes that Covert Cloak sets don't at the cost of being vulnerable to Fake Out. Life Orb allows for cleaner OHKOes such as OHKOing Rillaboom regardless of its defensive investment as well as boosting Flare Blitz, while Sharp Beak is an option if you prefer not taking recoil at the cost of damage output, such as only having a 60% chance to OHKO the previously mentioned Rillaboom.
  • The choice of Tera type is mostly dependent on personal preference. Tera Ghost prevents Fake Out, Extreme Speed, and other priority moves from breaking Gale Wings. Tera Flying is used for damage, allowing Sharp Beak and Life Orb sets to cleanly OHKO Amoonguss, as well as some frail neutral types such as Delphox and Hisuian Typhlosion, with Brave Bird. Tera Grass gives a resistance to Water, Electric, and an important immunity to powder attacks; this is used to bypass opposing Rage Powders and Taunt an opposing Trick Room user on turn one.
  • Jolly is usually preferred for outspeeding Adamant Dragapult, Whimsicott, and Sneasler, but Adamant is also viable to maximize damage, allowing it to OHKO Amoonguss without Terastallization on Life Orb sets.
  • The last two moveslots are open to player preference and usually mix and matched, the usual 2 are Flare Blitz and Taunt, giving it an additional STAB move and extra utility, respectively, but Will-O-Wisp and Protect are also viable; the former cripples physical threats like Dondozo, and the latter is generally useful.

Vivillon.comments:
Teambuilding

  • Vivillon works well on offensive teams, acting as a fast sleep support Pokemon while still hitting hard into defensive pieces like Rillaboom and Amoonguss. Sleep Powder can shut down slower foes such as Annihilape and Primarina, keeping the momentum for offensive threats like Garchomp. Vivillon also works well on balance, specifically with Porygon2, redirecting or shutting down attacks for Porygon2 while also sitting next to Ursaluna as it uses Earthquake.

  • Thanks to Vivillon's Flying typing, it can be used next to Garchomp and its easily spammable Earthquake amazingly. Earthquake also forces threats such as Archaludon to go for Tera Grass, which then opens up Vivillon to hit hard with Hurricane. Vivillon can also put foes to sleep for Garchomp, which sets it apart from other Flying-types. Gholdengo is another solid partner for Vivillon, benefiting from redirection.

  • Vivillon loses to Maushold and Annihilape as a duo, as Annihilape threatens Vivillon after it Terastallizes, and Maushold can shut down Vivillon by outspeeding it and using Taunt. It can also struggle with Maushold and Archaludon as a duo, with Maushold this time threatening Population Bomb as well as Taunt while Archaludon can take down Vivillon with Electro Shot, Flash Cannon, and Draco Meteor. Garchomp and Gholdengo can patch up these holes; Garchomp's Earthquake hits hard into all of the aforementioned foes, while Gholdengo can do the same with Shadow Ball and Make It Rain. Garchomp also has the added benefit of Rough Skin, damaging Maushold for attacking.

Strategy Comments

  • Vivillon's main role is to put things to sleep with high Speed, hit decently hard, and redirect attacks to protect allies. Vivillon really shines when next to Garchomp, putting slower foes likes Pelipper to sleep and redirecting attacks such as Moonblast from Primarina and Draco Meteor from Hydreigon.

  • Vivillon can be used best in early-game situations and works really well in the lead or even in the back next to Gholdengo, spamming Sleep Powder while Gholdengo uses Make It Rain or using Rage Powder to allow Gholdengo to set up and sweep. Vivillon can also be used next to Primarina, with Hyper Voice and Sleep Powder forcing Tera Grass from foes such as Incineroar, which can then allow Vivillon to hit hard with Hurricane.

  • Vivillon can struggle with Pokemon like Incineroar chipping it down and breaking Focus Sash, and smart pivoting into Grass-types or Safety Goggles Pokemon can make it hard for Vivillon to do its job. For this, Incineroar can work to remove Safety Goggles with Knock Off and KO Grass-types with Flare Blitz. Tera Ghost is also great at preserving Focus Sash, while Protect and good pivoting of your own can help as well.

Support.description:
• Vivillon is a very good support Pokemon, providing redirection and fast sleep while dealing good damage. Compound Eyes helps make Vivillon more consistent as a support Pokemon, making Hurricane and Sleep Powder more accurate.

  • Hurricane does good damage to foes such as Amoonguss and Rillaboom as well as hitting common Tera Grass users like Archaludon, which are forced to Terastallize due to Sleep Powder. Rage Powder, even with Vivillon's low bulk, is able to soak up one or two attacks for allies such as Garchomp.

  • Focus Sash compensates for Vivillon's rather poor defensive stats, granting more turns for it to support its team, specifically allowing for more sleep opportunities.

  • Tera Ghost denies Fake Out from foes like Rillaboom and Incineroar and Extreme Speed from Dragonite, which helps with Vivillon's survivability, as it stops Focus Sash from being broken.

Incineroar.comments:
Teambuilding

  • Amoonguss works exceptionally well with Incineroar, protecting it from Water- and Fighting-type attacks such as Basculegion’s Wave Crash and Annihilape’s Drain Punch. Amoonguss also provides Incineroar with much appreciated healing. In return, Incineroar can handle Gholdengo and switch into Fire-types like Talonflame and Volcarona as well as removing opposing Safety Goggles with Knock Off.
  • Incineroar also works well with Gholdengo, providing Intimidate and Fake Out support to help it set up safely. Gholdengo also takes advantage of Incineroar’s ability to do great damage to Kingambit, considering Gholdengo can blow up Clefable and Sneasler that may attempt to protect Kingambit.
  • Porygon2 and Ursaluna can set up Trick Room and Substitute more easily thanks to Incineroar’s support. Ursaluna can then blow up Pokemon Incineroar struggles to damage like Archaludon and opposing Incineroar.
  • Incineroar can struggle to do its job against Pokemon that threaten it such as Pelipper, the Ursaluna formes, and Annihilape. Bulky support Incineroar can also feel passive at times because of its lackluster damage output, especially when it can’t use Parting Shot because of redirection or Taunt. Therefore, offensive Pokemon like Gholdengo and Ursaluna that can take on these threats and make up for Incineroar’s poor damage output are greatly appreciated.

Strategy Comments

  • Incineroar is an effective support Pokemon and pivot thanks to Fake Out, Intimidate, and its pivoting moves. This makes Incineroar strongest when it can switch in and slow down threats like Sneasler and Rillaboom. When using Taunt or Will-O-Wisp, Incineroar can shut down opposing wincons like Porygon2’s Trick Room and Kingambit. Rage Powder from Amoonguss makes it easier for Incineroar to pivot in and out.
  • Incineroar is strong throughout the entire game; it's usually preserved throughout the game, as even switching it in is impactful, and a late-game Fake Out can be crucial regardless of how injured Incineroar is. Incineroar is notably strongest as a lead where it can threaten Fake Out and weaken opposing threats without risking any damage. Against Annihilape and Kingambit however, Incineroar likes to be paired with pieces that force them out before coming in, such as Gholdengo and Ursaluna. Assault Vest Incineroar can afford to stay in and do invaluable damage as an offensive piece occasionally, though it notably has to be a lot more careful against Amoonguss.
  • Incineroar’s biggest weaknesses are Annihilape and Kingambit, as they take advantage of Intimidate and can prove to be dangerous wincons with support. Pelipper and Ursaluna-B also prove troublesome, (AC) as they are powerful attackers unaffected by Intimidate. Incineroar relies on teammates such as the aforementioned Gholdengo and Ursaluna to handle these threats along with Fake Out support. When Incineroar pivots in, it can also lead to a loss of momentum against setup Pokemon that can’t be flinched with Fake Out, such as Bulk Up Annihilape, Nasty Plot Gholdengo, and Substitute Ursaluna, so it must be careful when pivoting. Bulky support Incineroar’s damage output can often feel underwhelming, especially against opposing Incineroar. Assault Vest Incineroar has a tougher time providing support, notably having more trouble getting setup sweepers into position, since it lacks Parting Shot. This can make the mirror matchup tougher, as opposing Incineroar can position their threatening allies better.

Bulky Support.description:
• Incineroar excels as a support Pokemon and pivot thanks to its vast supportive movepool, Intimidate, and great typing, providing Incineroar with resistances to Gholdengo’s, Rillaboom’s, and Kingambit’s STAB moves.
  • Incineroar can utilize Taunt over Flare Blitz to shut down support Pokemon like Amoonguss and Trick Room from Porygon2. Incineroar can also use Will-O-Wisp over Flare Blitz to weaken physical attackers like Garchomp and especially Kingambit, which punishes Intimidate.
  • Safety Goggles is preferred, so Incineroar can reliably check and ignore Amoonguss. Sitrus Berry’s burst healing helps Incineroar avoid 2HKOs from attacks like Choice Specs Gholdengo’s Make it Rain and Pelipper’s Weather Ball after Terastallization.
  • Tera Ghost is preferred to grant Incineroar an immunity to Sneasler’s Close Combat and Dragonite’s Extreme Speed as well as a crucial immunity to Fake Out from opposing Incineroar and Rillaboom. Tera Grass can be used instead to grant Incineroar resistances to Water- and Ground-type moves such as Basculegion’s Wave Crash and Garchomp’s Stomping Tantrum. Tera Grass also provides an immunity to Spore and Rage Powder from Amoonguss if Safety Goggles have been removed with Knock Off or Incineroar is using Sitrus Berry.
  • The defensive EVs allow Incineroar to survive Garchomp’s Life Orb-boosted Stomping Tantrum and, after using Tera Ghost, Gholdengo’s Life Orb-boosted Shadow Ball and Choice Band Basculegion’s 100-Base Power Last Respects after Intimidate.

Assault Vest.description:
• Assault Vest Incineroar is a fantastic pivot thanks to its exceptional defenses and access to Fake Out. The extra bulk enables Incineroar to play more offensively with respectable Attack and Speed investment.
  • Assault Vest helps Incineroar take attacks from Pelipper, Ursaluna-B, and Archaludon.
  • Tera Grass is preferred due to the Spore and Rage Powder immunity on top of the valuable resistances to Ground- and Water-type moves, such as Basculegion’s Wave Crash and Garchomp’s Stomping Tantrum.
  • The Attack EVs allow Incineroar to almost always 2HKO Kingambit with Flare Blitz after Intimidate. The defensive investment ensures that Incineroar takes Annihilape’s +1 Drain Punch and avoids the 2HKO from Choice Scarf Hisuian Typhlosion’s Heat Wave after Terastallization. The Speed EVs enable Incineroar to outspeed Sneasler under Tailwind.
  • Bulky support Incineroar is more flexible and can use Parting Shot as its pivot move of choice. Assault Vest Incineroar trades this flexibility in exchange for vastly more special bulk and offensive prowess. Bulky support Incineroar doesn’t have to burn Terastallization to handle Amoonguss and can use Tera Ghost instead.

Primarina.comments:
Teambuilding

  • Primarina fits well on balance teams, as it benefits from utility moves like Fake Out, healing, and redirection support that allow it to attack freely while other Pokemon cover its weaknesses.
  • Primarina synergizes well with Sneasler, as Sneasler covers its Grass-type weakness. Additionally, Rillaboom offers Fake Out utility and passive Grassy Terrain recovery, benefiting a bulkier attacker like Primarina.
  • Electabuzz is an effective redirector, shielding Primarina from threats like Archaludon and Sneasler while also redirecting Spores from Amoonguss thanks to its Vital Spirit ability and providing speed control with Electroweb. Similarly, Magmar makes a great partner with its access to Vital Spirit and Follow Me. In addition, Magmar resists Rillaboom's Grass-type attacks and can use Will-O-Wisp to compensate for Primarina’s lower physical bulk.
  • Though Primarina sits in an awkward Speed tier, it can operate on teams with a Trick Room mode such as compositions with Porygon2 and Ursaluna.
  • Kingambit is a strong offensive partner for Primarina. With Primarina's chip damage, Kingambit can more easily secure KOs with Sucker Punch. Additionally, most Kingambit sets include Swords Dance, allowing it to punish passive plays and forcing the opponent to choose between Primarina or Kingambit to target.
  • Gholdengo is another common partner for Primarina, as they effectively cover each other's weaknesses. Primarina threatens Pokemon like Incineroar and Garchomp, which can beat Gholdengo, while Gholdengo walls and pressures threats like Sneasler, Rillaboom, and Amoonguss.

Strategy Comments

  • As a slower-paced offensive piece, Primarina excels when it's positioned to safely chip away at opponents. For instance, being alongside a redirection Pokemon allows it to unleash substantial chip damage with Hyper Voice. Due to its respectable bulk, Primarina can often continue using Hyper Voice until a Pokémon that poses a significant immediate threat, such as Rillaboom, enters the field.
  • The strategy with Primarina is to wait for the opportunity to establish a strong offensive position. Typically, this involves pivoting it around until it can come in and clean up effectively mid- or late-game.
  • As mentioned earlier, Rillaboom and Archaludon are significant threats; however, Sneasler effectively counters both. When facing opposing Sneasler or setup sweepers like Gholdengo or Volcarona, it's crucial to position Primarina correctly—either by placing it next to a redirector, so it can attack freely, or by utilizing other Pokemon to apply more immediate pressure. This is because Primarina is most effective when its consistent spread chip damage is sufficient to prevent it from being outpaced on offense.

Bulky Attacker.description:
• Primarina excels at dealing consistent damage and wearing down opposing Pokemon. Its strong offensive typing, high Special Attack, and ability to take advantage of STAB Hyper Voice with Liquid Voice make it a formidable threat. Additionally, it puts pressure on common metagame Pokemon like Incineroar and Garchomp.
  • Haze prevents setup Pokémon from exploiting Primarina's slower offensive pace. More importantly, it's often used to counter the Dondozo and Tatsugiri matchup.
  • While Throat Spray provides a power boost after using Hyper Voice, Life Orb offers more immediate damage, making it better suited for more aggressive teams. For example, Life Orb guarantees an OHKO on Hisuian Typhlosion with Hyper Voice while allowing Primarina to 2HKO Sneasler and Choice Specs Gholdengo with Hyper Voice. Sitrus Berry, on the other hand, enables Primarina to take on a more passive role, consistently enhancing its survivability. For instance, Sitrus Berry's recovery enables it to live two Stomping Tantrums from Life Orb Garchomp.
  • Tera Poison allows Primarina to resist both of Sneasler's STAB moves and, unlike the other two recommended Tera types, doesn't introduce many common weaknesses. Tera Steel gives Primarina an immunity to Poison-type moves like Sneasler's Dire Claw and a resistance to Steel-type attacks, making it particularly effective against Gholdengo's Make it Rain. Tera Grass, like Tera Poison and Tera Steel, offers a resistance to Grass-type moves from Pokemon like Rillaboom. It also provides a resistance to Electric-type attacks like Electro Shot from Archaludon, and an immunity to Spore, preventing Amoonguss from shutting it down.
  • With the given Defense and HP investment, Primarina is guaranteed to survive Grassy Glide from maximum Attack Rillaboom and a 100-Base Power Last Respects from non-Adaptability Choice Band Basculegion. The Special Defense investment ensures it can withstand Tera Steel Make it Rain from Choice Specs Gholdengo, Blood Moon from Life Orb Ursaluna-B, and two Freeze-Dry hits from Alolan Ninetales. The Special Attack investment gives Primarina a good chance to OHKO Garchomp with Moonblast and non-bulky Talonflame with Hyper Voice, while the Speed investment is designed to outspeed maximum Speed Maushold in Tailwind.

Kommo-o.comments:
Teambuilding

  • Kommo-o greatly appreciates redirection from Pokemon like Electabuzz and Amoonguss, allowing it to safely set up. Electabuzz can also use Taunt to prevent Haze from removing Kommo-o's boosts. Damage reduction like Intimidate and Will-O-Wisp from Incineroar and Magmar can also aid Kommo-o in setting up. Aurora Veil and dual screens from Alolan Ninetales and Grimmsnarl, respectively, can also help in damage reduction. Fake Out and healing from Rillaboom and its Grassy Terrain are helpful in helping with safe setup and longevity, respectively.
  • Gholdengo is a good partner, as it threatens Fairy-types like Hatterene and Clefairy. Sneasler can also threaten Fairy-types with Dire Claw. Kingambit is another good offensive partner, threatening Ghost-types like Dragapult that would otherwise wall out Body Press Kommo-o sets. Tyranitar can threaten Flying-types like Dragonite and Talonflame.
  • Kommo-o can struggle immensely against Fairy-types like Primarina and Psychic-type spam teams that include Pokemon like Indeedee-M. Dragonite is another issue, dealing a lot of damage and using Haze to remove Kommo-o's boosts. Dragonite also has Multiscale, weakening Kommo-o's damage. Steel-types like Gholdengo threaten good damage into the Fairy-types, while Dark-types like Incineroar can easily take attacks like Expanding Force from Psychic-type spam teams. Allies like Porygon2 and Grimmsnarl can threaten Dragonite for good damage with Ice Beam and Spirit Break, respectively.

Strategy Comments

  • Kommo-o's main role is to get set up and sweep or clean up. Kommo-o works best when next to support that helps it set up like redirection and Fake Out.
  • Kommo-o works well as a cleaner during the late-game, so aiming to remove pieces that might stop it like Dragonite is helpful. Reserving support like Electabuzz for Kommo-o can also be helpful, as it helps Kommo-o set up.
  • Haze is a big issue for Kommo-o, punishing it for setting up. Fast and powerful attackers like Dragapult can deal major damage before Kommo-o sets up or attacks. Fast Taunt from foes like Maushold is a check to Kommo-o, that is, if you predict correctly whether or not Kommo-o sets up. Haze can be stopped by Taunt, and fast breakers or Taunt can be stopped by redirection from allies like Electabuzz.

Clangorous Soul.description:
• Clangorous Soul Kommo-o aims to set up and sweep or deal great amounts of damage to the majority of the metagame. It avoids Spore thanks to Overcoat or becomes immune to attacks like Hyper Voice thanks to Soundproof while enjoying the fact that there aren't that many Fairy-types in the format, allowing Clanging Scales to hit almost everything in the format for solid damage.
  • Clangorous Soul allows Kommo-o to set up, which can be aided with redirection. Clanging Scales can deal good spread damage while also boosting Kommo-o's Special Attack with Throat Spray if it hasn't used Clangorous Soul. Flamethrower can threaten Steel-types like Gholdengo that resist Clanging Scales while hitting hard into metagame threats like Rillaboom and Alolan Ninetales. Aura Sphere, on the other hand, is a good STAB option that also hits Steel-types, doing good damage into Pokemon like Archaludon and Kingambit.
  • Throat Spray's extra Special Attack boost in conjunction with Clangorous Soul allows Flamethrower to OHKO Gholdengo, Kingambit, and Alolan Ninetales or Aura Sphere to OHKO Tyranitar. Leftovers is good to heal back the damage dealt from Clangorous Soul, increasing its longevity.
  • Tera Fire grants a resistance to Fairy-type attacks and Make it Rain and gives Flamethrower a STAB boost. Tera Steel grants more defensive properties, letting it resist Dragon- and Flying-type attacks from Pokemon such as Hydreigon and Dragonite.
  • 188 Speed EVs let Kommo-o outspeed Pelipper while outpacing Sneasler after a Clangorous Soul. The Special Attack investment lets the first Kommo-o set OHKO Kingambit with +2 Flamethrower while also OHKOing Archaludon with Aura Sphere after the same boosts. The alternative EV spread outspeeds Rillaboom without any boosts while taking under 50% from Scale Shot from Dragonite when Terastallized into Fire.
  • Although Clangorous Soul sets are more destructive than Iron Defense sets, losing health early can lead to Kommo-o easily getting KOed by strong neutral attacks. Unlike Iron Defense, Clangorous Soul is not an easily spammable move and is really only used once per game.

Iron Defense.description:
• With Iron Defense, Kommo-o is able to set up and stay on the field for a long time, taking attacks from Pokemon like Sneasler and Rillaboom.
  • Iron Defense and Body Press are Iron Defense Kommo-o's main source of damage, hitting a lot of the metagame really well, like Porygon2 and Ursaluna-B.
  • Leftovers increases Kommo-o's longevity, making it incredibly difficult to remove.
  • The EVs are physically defensive to deal more damage with Body Press, OHKOing both Ursaluna formes after a Iron Defense. The Special Defense EVs let it survive a Life Orb-boosted Blood Moon from Ursaluna-B. The second EV spread can survive Tera Fire Choice Specs Eruption from Timid Hisuian Typhlosion.
  • Iron Defense Kommo-o is quite vulnerable to special attacks, with no way to boost its Special Defense. It can also be quite slow, so faster threats can remove Kommo-o before it gets boosts or disrupt Kommo-o, preventing set up.

Bulky Support.description:
Set Details

  • Lunala leverages its high bulk with Shadow Shield and wide movepool to support its team, mainly protecting it from spread attacks such as Astral Barrage and Glacial Lance with Wide Guard. Its high Special Attack and strong Ghost- and Fairy-type attacks allow it to weaken the opposing team over the course of a game, allowing its partners to clean up after it.
  • Moonblast is a great option to hit Dark-types such as Incineroar and Normal-types like Ursaluna, as well as OHKO both Urshifu formes.
  • Electric Seed allows Lunala to feel much less threatened by strong physical attacks such as Glacial Lance from Calyrex-I, Flare Blitz from Koraidon, and Headlong Rush from Ursaluna. This lets Lunala both set up and take down Trick Room or continue dealing damage.
  • Lunala's Special Attack investment allows it to 3HKO many bulky Pokemon, such as Zamazenta-C, Calyrex-I after Terastallization, and Amoonguss with Moongeist Beam. Its bulk allows it to survive Tera Fire Flare Blitz from Ability Shield Koraidon under Neutralizing Gas and Timid Choice Specs Miraidon Electro Drift half of the time.
  • Tera Fairy allows Lunala to resist Dark-type attacks such as Knock Off from Incineroar while being immune to Draco Meteor from Miraidon and removing Lunala's weakness to Ghost. It also allows Lunala to 3HKO Incineroar with Tera Fairy Moonblast.

Teambuilding

  • Lunala often struggles to stay safe without Terastallizing, mainly due to Dark- and Ghost-type attacks from Incineroar, Chi-Yu, Lunala, and Calyrex-S. As such, it is not hard to force it to Terastallize. It can also struggle against Urshifu-R, ignoring the Defense boost with Surging Strikes and only being affected by Shadow Shield on the first hit.
  • After Shadow Shield is broken, it can be quickly knocked out with strong neutral attacks such as Astral Barrage from Calyrex-S after Lunala has Terastallized, Electro Drift from Miraidon, and Flare Blitz from Koraidon. Lunala can also become very passive when weakened by moves such as Spirit Break, Parting Shot, and Snarl from Grimmsnarl and Incineroar.
  • Lunala requires Miraidon as a partner to activate its Electric Seed and appreciates bulky partners to protect itself, such as Incineroar. It works very well with Assault Vest Miraidon, as it allows both Restricted Pokemon on the team to soak up damage and use consistent strong attacks to chunk down foes, and Lunala can protect Miraidon from Glacial Lance with Wide Guard.
  • Ursaluna is also a great partner for it, as it can be very difficult to deny Trick Room from Lunala, allowing Ursaluna to get on the field and devastate with Facade or Headlong Rush, while Lunala cleans up foes that Ursaluna may not be able to take out in one hit. It also appreciates Pokemon that can clean up foes that are chipped down by Lunala, such as Urshifu-R.

Offensive Support.description:
Set Details

  • Equipped with versatile support options, a phenomenal defensive ability paired with great bulk, and solid offensive coverage, Lunala can be an extremely flexible option for many teams. Utilizing the combination of its Ghost typing and Wide Guard, Lunala can have very advantageous matchups into popular Restricted Pokemon like the Calyrex formes, Kyogre, Zamazenta-C, and Koraidon by blocking their strong STAB moves like Glacial Lance, Astral Barrage, and Water Spout with Wide Guard and being immune to Body Press and Close Combat thanks to its typing.
